title: Funded Futures Prop Firms Compared: Apex vs Topstep vs Leeloo (2025 Guide)
excerpt: Prop trading is no longer a niche experiment—it’s the gateway many traders use to access meaningful capital without putting their entire savings on the line.
content:
Prop trading is no longer a niche experiment—it’s the gateway many traders use to access meaningful capital without putting their entire savings on the line. This is especially true in futures trading, where contracts like ES (E-mini S&P 500), NQ (E-mini Nasdaq 100), and GC (Gold futures) demand serious margin if you trade them on your own account.

Prop firms solve that problem. With a few hundred dollars, you can attempt an evaluation that gives you access to $25,000, $50,000, $100,000 or more in notional capital.

But here’s the part most traders underestimate:
The prop firm you choose can be the difference between a smooth path to funded payouts and a constant loop of resets, rule violations, and frustration.

On the surface, Apex Trader Funding, Topstep, and Leeloo Trading look similar. They all offer:

  • Evaluations

  • Drawdown rules

  • Profit targets

  • Payouts

Underneath, the details are very different—and those details directly affect futures traders running strategies on ES, NQ, and GC.

This guide breaks down Apex vs Topstep vs Leeloo in a way that’s practical, not promotional—so you can choose the firm that actually fits your style and risk tolerance.

Why Apex, Topstep, and Leeloo Matter for Futures Traders

There are many futures prop firms out there—Bulenox, UProfit, Earn2Trade, and others. But Apex, Topstep, and Leeloo dominate the conversation for three reasons:

◇ They’ve been around long enough to prove they’re not fly-by-night operations.
◇ They focus heavily on U.S. futures traders.
◇ They’ve processed thousands of evaluations and funded accounts, so their rule sets are battle-tested.

In short, if you’re serious about funded futures trading, you will almost inevitably end up comparing these three.

At a glance:

  • Apex Trader Funding – Aggressive pricing, constant discounts, large scale potential.

  • Topstep – The long-term industry benchmark with structure, education, and trust.

  • Leeloo Trading – A trader-favorite balance of fair rules, scaling, and community support.

The Core Prop Firm Model (Stripped of Hype)

All three firms run on the same basic blueprint:

  1. You pay for an evaluation account.

  2. You trade under a defined rule set (profit target, max loss, consistency, etc.).

  3. If you pass, you’re offered a funded or funded-sim account.

  4. You keep a portion of your profits, and the firm keeps a share.

The variations—drawdown type, trailing logic, daily loss limits, payout schedule, news restrictions, scaling plans—are where the real differences live.

Those rule details decide:

  • How easily you can survive normal drawdowns.

  • Whether your style (scalping, swing trading, intraday momentum) fits.

  • How often you risk failing for technicalities rather than bad edge.

Apex Trader Funding: High Volume, Low Cost, High Responsibility

Apex Trader Funding has become the entry point for a huge number of futures traders because of one thing: discounts.

It’s not unusual to see 80–90% off promotions, where an evaluation that would normally cost over $100 becomes a $20–$30 monthly subscription. For many people, this is the cheapest way to get into futures prop trading.

But the pricing isn’t the only story.

Apex Key Features

  • Trailing Drawdown
    Apex uses a trailing drawdown that follows your equity, not just your balance, until you pass key thresholds.
    This is one of the most misunderstood—and most dangerous—elements for new traders. If you hit a strong open, then give back a chunk of profits intraday, you can trigger the trailing drawdown even if your balance is still above starting equity.

  • Multiple Accounts Allowed
    Apex is famous for allowing traders to run many accounts—sometimes 10, 20, or more. This makes Apex very attractive for automation and multi-account scaling.

  • Fast Payout Options
    Payouts can begin relatively early (for example, after a short period in the funded phase), though there are initial caps on payout amounts.

  • Aggressive Marketing and Promotions
    The constant discount environment draws in a large volume of traders—many of whom churn through evaluations repeatedly.

Who Apex Suits Best

  • ES and NQ intraday traders who understand trailing drawdowns and can protect equity swings.

  • Traders using automation tools or systematic strategies.

  • Those looking to run multiple funded accounts and scale via consistency and volume.

If you don’t understand how trailing drawdowns work in real time, Apex can feel brutal. If you do—and you pair it with rule-based execution—it becomes one of the most cost-effective ways to build a funded futures portfolio.

Topstep: Structure, Stability, and Professionalism

Topstep is the original heavyweight in the futures prop trading space. Long before the explosion of discount firms, Topstep was already funding traders and offering structured paths to live capital.

Where Apex wins on pricing, Topstep wins on credibility and stability.

Topstep Key Features

  • Balance-Based or Fixed Drawdown Style
    Compared to aggressive trailing equity models, Topstep’s approach to drawdown is generally seen as more forgiving. It’s easier to survive normal swings in ES or NQ without inadvertently tripping a technical failure.

  • Two-Step Evaluation
    Topstep requires traders to pass two phases, not just one. That might sound like a disadvantage, but it forces you to prove you can be consistent under more than one set of conditions. It builds good habits and filters out “lucky streak” trading.

  • Proven Payout Stability
    Topstep has a long track record of paying traders on time. Rules don’t change overnight, and the firm tends to avoid shock adjustments.

  • Education and Coaching
    Unlike most prop firms, Topstep leans heavily into education: webinars, coaching, trader development, and mindset support.

Who Topstep Suits Best

  • Traders who want a professional, structured environment similar to a traditional desk.

  • Those willing to pay more for predictability, education, and industry trust.

  • Futures traders who care as much about longevity and reputation as short-term payouts.

Topstep isn’t the cheapest path to funding. But if your goal is to build a career-level approach to futures prop trading, it’s one of the most stable partners available.

Leeloo Trading: Balanced Rules and a Trader-First Culture

Leeloo Trading sits between Apex and Topstep in many ways. It’s not as aggressively marketed as Apex and not as institutionally rigid as Topstep, but it has earned a loyal base of futures prop traders.

Many traders call Leeloo their “sweet spot” firm.

Leeloo Key Features

  • Balance-Based Drawdown
    Like Topstep, Leeloo’s drawdown generally stops trailing once you cross specific levels. That makes it much more forgiving for swing traders or those who want to hold ES, NQ, or GC for more than a quick scalp.

  • Scaling Plan
    Leeloo’s scaling rules encourage growing position size as the account grows, instead of jumping from 1 contract to 10 overnight. This is a big positive for traders who want structured growth.

  • Community Environment
    Leeloo leans into a more personal and community-driven tone, with strong Discord presence and approachable communication.

  • Multiple Accounts
    You can run multiple Leeloo accounts, though the culture around it leans more toward measured scaling rather than raw volume.

Who Leeloo Suits Best

  • Traders who want fair rules, breathing room, and a community feel.

  • ES, NQ, and GC traders who prefer balance-based risk rather than aggressive trailing equity rules.

  • Those looking for a middle ground between Apex’s cost and Topstep’s structure.

Apex vs Topstep vs Leeloo: Differences That Actually Impact You

On paper, many prop firm features look similar. In live trading, a handful of rule differences shape your entire experience.

1. Drawdown Type

  • Apex – Trailing drawdown that follows equity early on. Great for tight risk scalpers, unforgiving for traders who let open profits swing.

  • Topstep – More balance-based drawdown designs, easier on traders who understand risk but don’t want equity micromanagement.

  • Leeloo – Balance-based drawdown with swing-friendly behavior once you’re past certain levels.

For futures traders, drawdown logic is one of the most important details to understand before you commit.

2. Evaluation Structure

  • Apex – Typically single-step evaluations, quick to pass if you’re disciplined.

  • Topstep – Two-step evaluations, forcing consistency and better long-term habits.

  • Leeloo – Single-step style as well, offering a faster route to funded status.

If your edge is already proven, single-step might appeal. If you want structure and development, Topstep’s multi-step path can be a strength rather than a hurdle.

3. Cost and Entry

  • Apex – Usually the cheapest due to constant sales.

  • Topstep – Higher ongoing evaluation cost, but stable and predictable.

  • Leeloo – Sits in the middle—more affordable than Topstep, not as aggressively discounted as Apex.

If you plan to run many evaluations, Apex becomes attractive. If you prefer fewer, more meaningful evaluations, Leeloo or Topstep may fit better.

4. Payout Terms

  • Apex – Fast, early payouts with initial caps. Good for those seeking quick proof of concept.

  • Topstep – Conservative but reliable payout timelines.

  • Leeloo – Competitive early payouts and flexible structures once you’re consistent.

In all three cases, once you’re proven and rule-compliant, futures prop payouts can become a predictable income line.

5. Culture and Firm Personality

  • Apex – High-energy, promotional, volume-driven.

  • Topstep – Professional, education-driven, institution-like.

  • Leeloo – Community-centered, relationship-focused, trader-first tone.

This “soft” factor matters more than most traders admit. You’re effectively choosing a business partner, not just a discount code.

ES, NQ, and GC Traders: Who Fits Where?

To make the comparison concrete, imagine three common futures traders.

ES Intraday Scalper

  • Focus: Quick 2–3 point moves on ES with tight stops.

  • Challenge: Equity swings during volatility, risk of tripping trailing drawdown.

Better fit:

  • Leeloo or Topstep with balance-based or end-of-day drawdown logic if you tend to let trades breathe.

  • Apex if you keep stops tight and never let big open profit swings reverse.

NQ Momentum Trader

  • Focus: Fast, directional trades on NQ around open and key levels.

  • Challenge: Higher volatility, larger intraday swings, emotional risk.

Better fit:

  • Apex for multi-account scaling and discounted retries, especially if paired with automation to control rules.

  • Leeloo if you want more breathing room once funded and plan to size gradually.

GC Swing / Intraday Hybrid Trader

  • Focus: Holding GC around news, sessions, or key macro days with wider stops.

  • Challenge: Sudden spikes around events, risk of tripping intra-session drawdown.

Better fit:

  • Topstep or Leeloo, where drawdown rules are friendlier to holding positions within a defined risk framework.

  • Apex only if you’re extremely precise with risk and don’t allow large unrealized swings.

Automation, Compliance, and Why Most Traders Still Fail

Most traders do not fail futures prop firm evaluations because they lack edge. They fail because they:

  • Break daily loss limits

  • Misjudge trailing drawdowns

  • Trade through news restrictions

  • Overtrade out of frustration

This is where automation and rule-based execution become a genuine advantage.

With a structured system:

  • A planner like Dr. Markets can build sessions around firm-specific rules, event calendars, and volatility conditions.

  • An executor like TradeRx can enforce compliance in real time—blocking trades that would break drawdown, trading hours, or consistency expectations.

  • Multi-account traders can run Apex, Topstep, and Leeloo side by side, with configurations tailored to each rulebook.

Instead of treating prop firms as enemies, you start operating as the kind of trader they want to keep funded: consistent, disciplined, and predictable.

How to Decide Which Firm to Start With

When you strip away the noise, choosing between Apex, Topstep, and Leeloo comes down to a few honest questions:

  • Do you value lowest cost or highest stability?

  • Are you primarily scalping, swing trading, or doing a blend?

  • Do you plan to operate one funded account or many?

  • How comfortable are you with trailing drawdown mechanics?

  • Do you want education and coaching, or are you bringing a mature edge already?

A simple way to frame it:

  • Choose Apex if you want low-cost entry, high scale, and are willing to master trailing drawdown with discipline or automation.

  • Choose Topstep if you want structure, education, longevity, and industry trust.

  • Choose Leeloo if you want a balanced rule set, strong community, and flexible path to scaling.

Apex, Topstep, and Leeloo each offer a valid route to funded futures trading. None of them is “the best” in isolation. They’re only “best” when matched to the right trader, the right strategy, and the right risk mindset.

If your goal is to stop resetting, stop fighting rule books, and start building funded futures accounts that actually survive and pay, the next step isn’t just choosing a firm—it’s choosing to trade in a way that respects that firm’s rules by design, not by hope.
